abstract.p: Tom Cova letter on increasing development in wildland areas; warns of urgent need for good emergency preparedness plans, such as those carried out in Los Alamos during recent fire (S)

block.p: Re ''Population Shift in the West Raises Wildfire Concerns'' (front page, May 30): Development is proceeding in many wildland areas without corresponding improvements in the primary transportation network. This means that evacuating a community today can be much more difficult than 30 years ago.

Los Alamos is a model in emergency preparedness, with detailed evacuation plans and a highly informed and responsive public. Its initial evacuation of 11,000 residents in a matter of hours with only two exiting roads set a new land-speed record for urban wildfire evacuation.

Re ''Population Shift in the West Raises Wildfire Concerns'' (front page, May 30): Development is proceeding in many wildland areas without corresponding improvements in the primary transportation network. This means that evacuating a community today can be much more difficult than 30 years ago.

Los Alamos is a model in emergency preparedness, with detailed evacuation plans and a highly informed and responsive public. Its initial evacuation of 11,000 residents in a matter of hours with only two exiting roads set a new land-speed record for urban wildfire evacuation.
Unprepared communities can expect a wildfire evacuation characterized by confusion and traffic congestion. Increasing preparedness in these communities should be a national priority.
TOM COVA Salt Lake City, June 1, 2000
The writer is an assistant professor of geography at the University of Utah.
